section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards (Gg, Hh), Alphabet Books (A Good Game and Hearts), drawing and writing supplies

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Biblioburro. We saw the letter g in the word good-bye and the letter h in the word hold.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Gg Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for letters Gg. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is uppercase G. The letter G makes the /g/ sound you hear in the word goat. This is lowercase g. The letter g makes the /g/ sound you hear in gift.

Teach Hh Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for the letters Hh. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is uppercase H. The letter H makes the /h/ sound you hear in the word hat. This is lowercase h. The letter h makes the /h/ sound you hear in heart.
Explain the Activity Share A Good Game. Today we will read this book about the letters Gg. Then we will read a book about the letters Hh.
Read Read aloud A Good Game and use the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Stomp your soccer feet when you hear a word that begins with the /g/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Read Read aloud Hearts and use the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Make a heart when you hear a word that begins with the /h/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Model writing uppercase and lowercase letters Gg and Hh. Provide drawing and writing supplies. Guide children in practicing forming their letters.

As you read A Good Game, stop at each word that begins with the letter Gg. Have children say /g/ and the word that begins with Gg. Repeat with Hearts and the letter Hh. Some children will benefit from tracing letters in trays of salt or sand.

For a challenge, after reading each story, ask children to try to recall all the words that begin with the target sound and letter. Then invite children to name any other words they know that begin with that letter and sound.

In Spanish, the letter g has a hard /g/ sound when it is followed by the vowels a, o, and u: gato, gordo, gusta. When it is followed by the vowels i and e, it is soft, making the /h/ sound: gimnasio, general.
In Spanish, the letter h is always silent. You might try to pretend it is invisible, too, when you see words with h’s. For example, the verb hay is pronounced like the English word eye.

Offer accommodations for visually impaired children to ensure children are included. If children will not be able to fairly participate in finding words, you might make a larger copy of the letter and word, highlighting the letter.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Plastic numbers or number tiles

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we revisited Biblioburro, a story about a man who carries books to children who have none. He saw the problem and worked very hard to solve it by bringing the books to children who needed them.
Just like Luis, we will first figure out what problem we have and then figure out steps that will help us solve it. We will persist until the problem is solved.
Today we have a number problem to solve. The numbers are all mixed up! We need to put these numbers in order. Let’s see if you and your partner can solve this problem!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model/Teach Tell children that working with a partner can be challenging. Encourage them to show initiative and tell their partners their ideas, and to persist and complete the task as a team.
Set Up Give each pair of children a handful of numbers, ranging from one to ten.
Ask What problem do you think you have? Help children formulate the idea that the numbers should be in order. Then ask children to work with their partners and figure how what to do.
Extend Have children work until you say “Stop.” Then see how far they have come and invite them to share what they did.
Talk About Persisting Invite children to reflect on the activity. What was the problem we had with the numbers? How did you solve it?
Some children may be intimidated by the thought of sharing their ideas because they fear they will not succeed. Remind children to be respectful of one another’s ideas and accomplishments.

Make the game a little more difficult for children who may see the tasks as very easy to complete by adding another variable to the activity. For example, have them count backwards and arrange the numbers from ten to one.

Make sure children know the names of the numbers in English before they begin. Have them count from one to ten in their home language as well. Pair an English learner with an English speaker for this activity if possible.
Help children who get frustrated to keep working on the task. Emphasize that it’s fine if something doesn’t work right away, because that is part of being persistent.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Biblioburro, various colors of play clay

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we reread Biblioburro and talked about the things Luis saw on his trip through the jungle to the town of El Tormento. Remember, we call this jungle a rainforest. Lots of plants and animals live in a rainforest.
Let’s make our own rainforest, like the one in the book. Let’s look at the pictures the illustrator drew. Let’s use our play clay to make the things we see!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model/Teach Before starting, browse the book together, pointing out the stream, hills, animals, and plants.
Ask What word names what you made? If children can’t answer, say something such as, I see you made a beautiful butterfly.
Repeat Repeat as children create more and more things for their rainforest environments. Encourage and compliment creative efforts.
Extend Set out the creations. Have children talk about what they observe, comparing and contrasting with support.
Talk About the Jungle Help children compare and contrast what Luis saw on his way to see the children with what children see on their way to school.
section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: Did you see any animals on your way to school? Which ones?
Did you see any trees or plants on your way to school?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: If children have a hard time choosing something to make, you might suggest something such as a butterfly or a bird. You may want to help with the shaping of the figure by helping children roll play clay into balls.

Assign pairs and have them work together to create as many things as they can in the time assigned. When the time is up, give them paper and help them label their creations. Suggest children at least try to write the first letter of the word that names the object they made.

Some of the names of the land features may be new vocabulary to children, especially children learning English. Help children learn how the new words are said by segmenting new words into syllables first, having children clap for each syllable as they say it. Children can clap faster as they pronounce the syllables closer together until they have blended them into words. Make sure to reference a picture of each feature as children learn its name.

If children are unable to sculpt with clay, allow them to use a medium more accessible to their abilities. For example, you may provide a long paintbrush and an easel for children who have trouble making or manipulating small objects.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Activity Cards

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we looked at the Big Chart of Big Ideas and learned about some of the helpers in our community.

Now, we’re going to learn more about helpers in our community. Each of you will choose a card that shows a helper in our community. Then, without talking, you will act like the helper on your card. The rest of us will guess which helper you are pretending to be!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Before doing the activity, you may wish to review the cards with children to make sure they recognize the helper in the picture and understand what each does.

Ask Invite one child to choose a card and act it out. After the other children have correctly guessed the helper, ask, How does this person help their community? Guide discussions by asking questions that will help children reach the answer on their own.
Extend Repeat the activity until each child has had a turn, or all the cards have been used.
Repeat Continue the activity, using the next picture card. Allow pairs to make up scenes in which the helper assists a community member.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: What helpers do we see in our school community?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Guide children to discuss the role of the principal, office staff, bus drivers, and other school helpers.
If children have a difficult time acting like the helper on the card, step in as an “assistant” to act out the job alongside the child.
If children enjoy the activity and request a more challenging one, ask them to think of community helpers other than those listed on the cards and act out their roles.

Children may be familiar with the words in their home languages that name these helpers. Encourage children to share the words with the group. Help children decide what they will do to act out what the helpers do before you call on them.

Some children may not be able to act out a role due to struggles with gross motor skill development or disabilities. In this case, modify the activity by allowing children to say clue words—but not the actual name of the helper—rather than acting out the role. Assist with clues as needed.
